item.title: Furlough support scheme to be extended in Budget until September
item.description: The plan will be announced in Wednesday's Budget, while more self-employed will also be eligible for help.

item.title: Calls for Nicola Sturgeon to quit over Alex Salmond revelations
item.description: Newly published documents raise further questions about the Alex Salmond saga.

item.title: Brazil variant: Search for mystery case narrows to 379 households
item.description: The health secretary says 379 households in south-east England are being contacted.

item.title: BBC Three will return to TV screens after six-year break
item.description: The channel will make a comeback, after scoring hits with Normal People and Fleabag online.

item.title: Aerial footage of Exeter bomb exploding
item.description: The controlled explosion of a World War Two bomb in Exeter has left a crater in the ground and properties with "structural damage".

item.title: Eurovision Song Contest travel 'necessary', organisers say
item.description: Participants from 41 countries will head to the Netherlands for this year's contest under new plans.

item.title: Manchester Arena attack: Firefighters 'felt shame' at being held back
item.description: A crying paramedic asked why crews were not helping at the scene of the bombing, an inquiry hears.

item.title: 2021 Rugby World Cup set to be postponed for year
item.description: The Rugby World Cup 2021 is set to be postponed until next year following a recommendation by governing body World Rugby.

item.title: Coronavirus: Texas moves to lift mask mandate and ease Covid rules
item.description: Texas's mask mandate will be lifted and businesses allowed to reopen fully, Governor Abbott says.

item.title: Bunny Wailer: Reggae legend who found fame with Bob Marley dies, aged 73
item.description: The musician was a founding member of The Wailers, alongside his childhood friend Bob Marley

item.title: Circuit-breaker lockdown for Isle of Man
item.description: The island will return to a three-week lockdown after a sharp rise in unexplained coronavirus cases.

item.title: Pontins used 'undesirables list' of Irish surnames
item.description: The holiday firm promises to change after disclosure of a list to screen out Gypsies and Travellers.

item.title: Glow-in-the-dark sharks found off New Zealand coast
item.description: The sharks live in deep waters and are thought to use light as a form of camouflage.

item.title: The Papers: Furlough extension and 'last chance for pubs'
item.description: The newspapers preview the chancellor's Budget on Wednesday, focusing on the furlough extension.

item.title: Ex-Bristol student unable to read at 13 now studying for PhD
item.description: William Carter, now studying in California, struggled academically until his dyslexia was diagnosed.

item.title: Human origins: 'Little Foot' fossil's big journey out of Africa
item.description: How the priceless skull of an ancient ancestor was brought to the UK from South Africa for study.

item.title: The Crown: Emma Corrin on finishing Diana role, Harry's comments, and Golden Globe win
item.description: The Golden Globe winner says it "makes sense" for her to leave at the end of The Crown's fourth season.

item.title: Covid and dementia - 'let them see their families'
item.description: Actress Ruthie Henshall is calling for more visiting access to family members in care homes.

item.title: Timelapse of Indonesia volcano erupting
item.description: The latest eruption from Mount Sinabung in North Sumatra sends ash up to 5km (3.1 miles) into the air.

item.title: Migrating flamingos turn Mumbai lakes into 'sea of pink'
item.description: Thousands of flamingos migrate to western India every year in search for food and nesting grounds.

item.title: The seven key questions facing Nicola Sturgeon
item.description: The answers given by Scotland's first minister in evidence to a Holyrood committee could be crucial for her political future.

item.title: The extraordinary rise and fall of trainer Gordon Elliott
item.description: Profile of Irish racehorse trainer Gordon Elliott, who faces an inquiry after being pictured sat on a dead horse.

item.title: Aston Martin: The billionaire building 'a British Ferrari'
item.description: Lawrence Stroll, executive chairman of Aston Martin, tells the BBC he wants to build a firm with a "luxury profile".

item.title: Fortnite: From piano player to pro gamer - aged just eight
item.description: Joseph Deen tells the BBC about his ambitions after signing with a professional esports team.

item.title: Covid-19: Can more mayors heal the 'North-South divide'?
item.description: Local leaders are pushing for more devolution, as England eases out of lockdown.

item.title: How rape allegations have rocked Australian politics
item.description: A political adviser's accusation has prompted other women to come forward with their own allegations.

item.title: 'Fake accounts used my pictures to sell sex'
item.description: Women tell BBC Scotland how scammers used their images on fake accounts advertising sex work websites.

item.title: Man City have overcome winter 'hell' with 21-game winning run - Guardiola
item.description: Pep Guardiola believes Manchester City have "come through hell to do something incredible" by extending their winning run to 21 games with victory against Wolves.

item.title: Parliamentary inquiry to consider link between sport & brain injury
item.description: A parliamentary inquiry, due to start on 9 March, will look at the links between head trauma and dementia.

item.title: Premiership may release Scotland players for rescheduled France game
item.description: Premiership Rugby is prepared to relax its rules to allow Scotland players to feature in a rearranged Six Nations match against France.

item.title: Seven-time world champion Hendry loses comeback match
item.description: Stephen Hendry loses his first match since coming out of retirement against Matthew Selt in the first round of the Gibraltar Open.

item.title: Former footballer Whittingham's stairs fall death 'accidental'
item.description: Midfielder Peter Whittingham, 35, suffered a traumatic head injury at the pub nearly a year ago.

item.title: Real Madrid willing to sell Varane to Man Utd - Wednesday's football gossip
item.description: Real Madrid willing to sell Varane to Man Utd, Bale expects a full pay-out, Chelsea still monitoring Donnarumma, plus more.

item.title: Ian St John obituary: 'An iconic Liverpool figure who went on to illuminate TV screens'
item.description: Ian St John, who has died aged 82, was one of the iconic figures in Liverpool's history before going on to enjoy a hugely successful career in TV.

item.title: Budget 2021: What is it and when will it happen?
item.description: The Budget - when is it, what does it do and what should we expect to hear from the chancellor?

item.title: Budget 2021: What we know so far about Sunak's spending plans
item.description: From money for the arts to help for small firms, here are the spending plans announced so far.

item.title: Budget 2021: Five things to look out for from Rishi Sunak
item.description: Tax rises and an extension of Covid support are both tipped to be announced in this week’s Budget.

item.title: Covid: Can I go on furlough and will it be extended?
item.description: Furlough will be extended until the end of September, the Chancellor will announce on Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are the self-employed getting in the Budget?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a loss of income?

item.title: Budget 2021: 'Furlough is a lifeline, I hope they extend it'
item.description: More support for jobs is expected in Chancellor Rishi Sunak's Budget, but will it be enough?

item.title: Coronavirus: NI's five-step plan to ease lockdown
item.description: BBC News NI explains the stages of the executive's plan for easing the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: How much will it cost the UK and how will we pay?
item.description: The pandemic is costing the government hundreds of billions of pounds. Where will it all come from?

item.title: What are the Brazil, South Africa and UK variants and will vaccines work?
item.description: More cases are being found in the UK, including a variant first seen in Brazil.

item.title: Covid: When will schools reopen?
item.description: All students in England can return to classrooms from 8 March as part of the plans to ease lockdown.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As schools remain closed to most pupils, the BBC is offering a wealth of educational material.

item.title: When does the stamp duty holiday in England and Northern Ireland end?
item.description: Stamp duty changes introduced to boost the housing market are due to end in March.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of new variants of Covid-19.
